title: Linear Convergence of Diffusion Models Under the Manifold Hypothesis

sections.text:
#### Abstract

Score-matching generative models have proven successful at sampling from complex highdimensional data distributions. In many applications, this distribution is believed to concentrate on a much lower $d$-dimensional manifold embedded into $D$-dimensional space; this is known as the manifold hypothesis. The current best-known convergence guarantees are either linear in $D$ or polynomial (superlinear) in $d$. The latter exploits a novel integration scheme for the backward SDE. We take the best of both worlds and show that the number of steps diffusion models require in order to converge in Kullback-Leibler (KL) divergence is linear (up to logarithmic terms) in the intrinsic dimension $d$. Moreover, we show that this linear dependency is sharp.

## 1 Introduction

Score-matching generative models Ho et al. (2020); Song et al. (2021) such as diffusion models have become a leading paradigm for generative modeling. They achieve state-of-the-art results in many domains including audio/image/video synthesis Evans et al. (2024); Dhariwal and Nichol (2021); Ho et al. (2022), molecular modeling Watson et al. (2023), and recently text generation Lou et al. (2024). Informally, diffusion models take samples from a distribution in $\mathbb{R}^{D}$, gradually corrupt them with Gaussian noise, and then learn to reverse this process. Once trained, a diffusion model can turn noise into new samples from the data distribution by iteratively applying the denoising procedure.

Due to the empirical success of diffusion models, there has been a push Oko et al. (2023); Wibisono et al. (2024); Wu et al. (2024) to better understand their theoretical properties, in particular, their convergence guarantees.

An important question is to determine the iteration complexity of diffusion models. In this paper, this refers to the number of steps diffusion models require in order to converge in Kullback-Leibler divergence to the original distribution regularized by a small amount of Gaussian noise. Assuming only the existence of a second moment, Benton et al. (2024) prove that the iteration complexity is at most linear (up to logarithmic factors) in $D$.

While this result is tight in the general case, many real-world distributions actually have a lowdimensional structure. The assumption that a distribution lives on a $d$-dimensional manifold is called the manifold hypothesis, see e.g. Bengio et al. (2013). This hypothesis has been supported by empirical evidence in many settings, e.g. image data, in which diffusion models are particularly successful. Therefore, the study of diffusion models under this assumption has garnered increased interest Kadkhodaie et al. (2024); Tang and Yang (2024); Pidstrigach (2022).

Recently Li and Yan (2024) have shown that there is a special discretization design guaranteeing an iteration complexity of $d^{4}$ in the intrinsic dimension $d$. The current Azangulov et al. (2024) best-known bound scales as $d^{3}$.

# Our Contribution 

In this work, we improve upon these results and show that the number of steps diffusion models require to converge in KL divergence is linear (up to logarithmic terms) in the intrinsic dimension $d$. This is formalized in 10. Additionally, we prove that the linear dependency is sharp.

The proof follows the structure of Chen et al. (2023b) and Benton et al. (2024) combined with a result from Azangulov et al. (2024) providing bounds on the score function depending only on the intrinsic dimension $d$. A key insight of our proof exploits the inherent martingale structure in diffusion processes. As we show, with the right SDE discretization, the corresponding error can be represented as a sum of easy-to-control martingale increments leading to a very concise argument.

We posit that this scaling is one of the major reasons why diffusion models are able to perform so well on tasks such as synthetic image generation. While the extrinsic dimension of image datasets is very large, e.g. $\approx 1.5 \cdot 10^{5}$ for ImageNet, Pope et al. (2021) estimate that the true intrinsic dimension is much lower, e.g. around 50 for ImageNet. Our result implies that the number of steps diffusion models need to sample scales as the latter rather than the former. This helps explain why diffusion models are able to generate crisp image samples with less than 1000 iterations Ho et al. (2020). We note that this is not the discretization generally used in practice; however, a single-line modification to existing implementations would result in this discretization scheme.

In Section 2, we give an overview of diffusion models, our assumptions and the discretization scheme that we use. We introduce our main result in Section 4 and give its proof in Section 5. We conclude in Section 6.

Concurrent work: Two weeks after the first version of our work was made publicly available, an independent work appeared by Huang et al. (2024) who derive similar bounds. In addition, they relax some of our assumption on the support and boundedness of the measure.

## 2 Preliminaries
### 2.1 Diffusion Models

Suppose we want to generate samples from a distribution $\mu$ on $\mathbb{R}^{D}$. Diffusion models solve this by first specifying a forward noising process $\left\{X_{t}\right\}_{t \in[0, T]}$ up to some time $T$. This process is defined as the evolution of data $X_{0} \sim \mu$ according to an Ornstein-Uhlenbeck (OU) SDE

$$
\left\{\begin{array}{l}
d X_{t}=-X_{t} d t+\sqrt{2} d B_{t}, \quad t \in(0, T] \\
X_{0} \sim \mu
\end{array}\right.
$$

where $\left\{B_{t}\right\}_{t \in[0, T]}$ is a Brownian motion on $\mathbb{R}^{D}$. Letting $c_{t}:=\exp (-t)$ and $\sigma_{t}^{2}:=1-\exp (-2 t)$, we note that $X_{t} \stackrel{\text { first }}{=} c_{t} X_{0}+\sigma_{t} Z_{D}$ where $Z_{D} \sim \mathcal{N}\left(0, \operatorname{Id}_{D}\right)$. We use $p_{t}$ to denote the marginal density of $X_{t}$.

The reverse process $\left\{Y_{t}\right\}_{t \in[0, T]}:=\left\{X_{T-t}\right\}_{t \in[0, T]}$, under mild assumptions Anderson (1982), satisfies

$$
\left\{\begin{array}{l}
d Y_{t}=\left(Y_{t}+2 \nabla \log p_{T-t}\left(Y_{t}\right)\right) d t+\sqrt{2} d B_{t}^{\prime}, \quad t \in(0, T] \\
Y_{0} \sim p_{T}
\end{array}\right.
$$

where $\left\{B_{t}^{\prime}\right\}_{t \in[0, T]}$ is another Brownian motion on $\mathbb{R}^{D}$. By generating samples $Y_{0} \sim p_{T}$ and then simulating (1) up to time $T$, we can obtain samples $Y_{T} \sim \mu$ from the data distribution. The main idea behind diffusion models is to simulate these dynamics approximately since neither $p_{T}$ nor the score function $s_{t}:=\nabla \log p_{t}$ are known.

In practice, we solve these problems by building an approximate process $\hat{Y}_{t}$. Due to the exponential convergence of the OU process to a standard normal distribution, for a sufficiently large $T$, we have that $p_{T} \approx \mathcal{N}\left(0, \operatorname{Id}_{D}\right)$. So, we initialize as $\hat{Y}_{0} \sim \mathcal{N}\left(0, \operatorname{Id}_{D}\right)$. Second, we learn a score approximation

$\hat{s}_{t} \approx s_{t}$ which is used instead of the true score function. The approximation $\hat{s}_{t}$ is usually parameterized by neural networks and trained via a denoising score-matching objective.

Finally, we note that the $\operatorname{SDE}$ (1) cannot be simulated exactly and instead a discretization scheme must be introduced. More precisely, first, in order to ensure numerical stability, an early stopping time $\delta>0$ is chosen. Next, the interval $[0, T-\delta]$ is divided into $K$ time steps $0=t_{0}<t_{1}<\ldots<t_{K}=T-\delta$. The final discretization is given by

$$
\left\{\begin{array}{l}
\hat{Y}_{t_{k+1}}=\alpha_{k} \hat{Y}_{t_{k}}+\beta_{k} \hat{s}_{T-t_{k}}\left(\hat{Y}_{t_{k}}\right)+\eta_{k} Z_{k}, \quad 0 \leq k<K \\
\hat{Y}_{t_{0}} \sim \mathcal{N}\left(0, \operatorname{Id}_{D}\right)
\end{array}\right.
$$

where $Z_{k} \stackrel{i.i.d.}{\sim} \mathcal{N}\left(0, \operatorname{Id}_{D}\right)$ and $\alpha_{k}, \beta_{k}, \eta_{k}$ are real numbers. The discretization schedule $t_{0}<t_{1}<\ldots<t_{K}$ and coefficients $\alpha_{k}, \beta_{k}, \eta_{k}$ are hyper-parameters specifying the design of the sampling procedure. We discuss the choice of the discretization coefficients and their importance in Section 3, and we specify the discretization schedule $\left\{t_{k}\right\}$ that gives a linear in $d$ convergence rate in Section 4.

# 2.2 Assumptions and Notation 

Throughout the paper, we assume that the distribution $\mu$ satisfies the manifold hypothesis which we state more formally in the following.

Assumption 1. $\mu$ is supported on a smooth, compact, $d$-dimensional, $\beta \geq 2$-smooth manifold $M$ embedded into $\mathbb{R}^{D}$.

We also make the following assumption for ease of presentation. The general case is handled by rescaling and shifting.

Assumption 2. We assume $\operatorname{diam} M \leq 1$ and $0 \in M$.
Without any restrictions on the manifold $M$, we cannot hope to obtain bounds independent of the ambient dimension $D$. As an intuitive counter-example, consider $D$-dimensional Hilbert curves $M_{n}$, see Figure 1(a). In the limit, these curves cover the entire $D$ dimensional cube $M_{\infty}:=[0,1]^{D}$. Moreover, any measure on $M_{\infty}$ can be seen as a weak limit of measures on $M_{n}$. This makes sampling from $M_{n}$ (for large enough $n$ ) as hard as sampling from $M_{\infty}$, which according to (Benton et al., 2024, Appendix H) scales as at least $D$.

Therefore, we should place additional assumptions on the complexity of $\mu$ and $M$ in order to avoid such pathological cases. Informally (see details in Appendix A), the complexity of $M$ depends both on its global (volume) and local (smoothness) properties. We control its smoothness by introducing a scale $r>0$ at which $M$ is locally flat. To control the measure $\mu$, we assume that it has a density $p_{0}(d y)$ (w.r.t. the standard volume form $d y$ ) bounded from above and below. We assume logarithmic control over the discussed quantities.

Assumption 3. There is a constant $C>0$ such that $\operatorname{Vol} M \leq e^{d C}, r>e^{-C}$, and $e^{-d C} \leq p_{0} \leq e^{d C}$.
Note that we impose different assumptions on $r$ and $\operatorname{Vol} M$, this follows from a relation between the radius and volume of the $d$-dimensional sphere, i.e. $\operatorname{Vol} B_{d}(0, r) \propto r^{d}$.

Remark 4. Informally, on scales larger than $r$, the manifold $M$ is not flat anymore. So, if $M$ is corrupted by noise of magnitude greater than $r$, over-smoothing may destroy the geometric structure, see Figure 1(b). Diffusion models stopped at time $\delta$ add Gaussian noise proportional to $\sqrt{\delta}$. To capture the shape of $M$ the stopping time should be chosen to satisfy $\sqrt{\delta} \lesssim r$. Thus we should expect $\log \delta^{-1} \geq C$.

Recall that $\delta$ denotes the early stopping time, and $0=t_{0}<t_{1}<\ldots<t_{K}=T-\delta$ are the $K$ discretization time steps. Let $\gamma_{k}:=t_{k+1}-t_{k}$ be the $k$-th step size. We control the score estimation error of $\hat{s}_{t}$ as follows.

Assumption 5. The score network $\hat{s}_{t}(x)$ satisfies

$$
\sum_{k=0}^{K-1} \gamma_{k} \mathbb{E}\left\|\mathrm{~s}_{T-t_{k}}\left(X_{T-t_{k}}\right)-\hat{s}_{T-t_{k}}\left(X_{T-t_{k}}\right)\right\|^{2} \leq \varepsilon_{\text {score }}^{2}
$$

# 3 Discretization Scheme 

In this section, we describe a discretization scheme that allows for polynomial convergence in the intrinsic dimension $d$. The most popular discretization scheme (2) is the so called exponential integrator. This involves a naive approximation of (1) by

$$
\left\{\begin{array}{l}
d \hat{Y}_{t}=\left(\hat{Y}_{t}+2 \nabla \hat{s}_{T-t_{k}}\left(\hat{Y}_{t_{k}}\right)\right) d t+\sqrt{2} d B_{t}^{\prime}, \quad t \in\left[t_{k}, t_{k+1}\right) \\
\hat{Y}_{0} \sim p_{T}
\end{array}\right.
$$

where the score part of the drift is made piecewise-constant. The discretization coefficients $\alpha_{k}, \beta_{k}, \eta_{k}$ are then chosen so that (2) corresponds to solving (3) exactly.

However, as pointed out in Li and Yan (2024), the iteration complexity of the exponential integrator grows with $D$, and, actually, there is a unique setting of the discretization coefficients in (2) that yields an iteration complexity independent of $D$. It is given by

$$
\left\{\begin{array}{l}
\hat{Y}_{t_{k+1}}=c_{\gamma_{k}}^{-1} \hat{Y}_{t_{k}}+\frac{\sigma_{\gamma_{k}}^{2}}{c_{\gamma_{k}}} \hat{s}_{T-t_{k}}\left(\hat{Y}_{t_{k}}\right)+\sigma_{\gamma_{k}} \frac{\sigma_{T-t_{k+1}}}{\sigma_{T-t_{k}}} Z_{k}, \quad Z_{k} \stackrel{i.i.d.}{\sim} \mathcal{N}\left(0, \operatorname{Id}_{D}\right) \\
\hat{Y}_{t_{0}} \sim \mathcal{N}\left(0, \operatorname{Id}_{D}\right)
\end{array}\right.
$$

Remark 6. This discretization scheme corresponds to the DDPM update rule Ho et al. (2020).
In Appendix B, we provide a simple argument that derives (4) as a correction of (2). We summarize it below. We recall Tweedie's formula Robbins (1956) stating that

$$
s_{t}(x)=\frac{c_{t} \mathbb{E}\left[X_{0} \mid X_{t}=x\right]-x}{\sigma_{t}^{2}}=-\frac{\mathbb{E}\left[Z_{D} \mid X_{t}=x\right]}{\sigma_{t}}
$$

for $X_{t}=c_{t} X_{0}+\sigma_{t} Z_{D}$, where $X_{0} \sim \mu$ and $Z \sim \mathcal{N}\left(0, \operatorname{Id}_{D}\right)$ are independent. We recall (Azangulov et al., 2024, Theorem 15), which gives the following.

Theorem 7. Let $\mu$ be a measure satisfying Assumptions 1-3. Let $t>0$ and let $X_{t}=c_{t} X_{0}+\sigma_{t} Z_{D}$, where $X_{0} \sim \mu$ and $Z_{D} \sim \mathcal{N}\left(0, \operatorname{Id}_{D}\right)$ are independent. Then with probability at least $1-\delta$

$$
\left\|\sigma_{t} s\left(t, X_{t}\right)+Z_{D}\right\| \lesssim \sqrt{d\left(C+\max \left\{\log \left(c_{t} / \sigma_{t}\right), 0\right\}\right)+\log \delta^{-1}}
$$

In particular, substituting (5) into Theorem 7 and using that $\operatorname{diam} M \leq 1$

$$
\mathbb{E}\left[\left\|\mathbb{E}\left[X_{0} \mid X_{t}\right]-X_{0}\right\|^{2}\right] \lesssim d\left(C+\max \left\{\log \left(c_{t} / \sigma_{t}\right), 0\right\}\right)
$$

Thus, we propose to approximate the score $s_{t}\left(x_{t}\right)$ for $t<t^{\prime}$ by the following

$$
s_{t}\left(x_{t} \mid t^{\prime}, x_{t^{\prime}}\right):=\frac{c_{t} \mathbb{E}\left[X_{0} \mid X_{t^{\prime}}=x_{t^{\prime}}\right]-x_{t}}{\sigma_{t}^{2}}=c_{t^{\prime}-t}^{-1} \frac{\sigma_{t}^{2}}{\sigma_{t}^{2}} s_{t^{\prime}}\left(x_{t^{\prime}}\right)-\frac{x_{t}-c_{t^{\prime}-t}^{-1} x_{t^{\prime}}}{\sigma_{t}^{2}}
$$

By Theorem 7, this approximation induces an error that only scales with the intrinsic dimension $d$. We analogously define $\hat{s}_{t}\left(x_{t} \mid t^{\prime}, x_{t^{\prime}}\right)$ to be a correction of the score estimate $\hat{s}_{t}$ obtained by substituting $\hat{s}_{t^{\prime}}\left(x_{t^{\prime}}\right)$ instead of $s_{t^{\prime}}\left(x_{t^{\prime}}\right)$ into (6).
Proposition 8. The scheme (4) can be obtained by solving the following continuous-time dynamics

$$
\left\{\begin{array}{l}
d \hat{Y}_{t}=\left[\hat{Y}_{t}+2 \hat{s}_{T-t}\left(\hat{Y}_{t} \mid T-t_{k}, \hat{Y}_{t_{k}}\right)\right] d t+\sqrt{2} d B_{t}^{\prime}, \quad t \in\left[t_{k}, t_{k+1}\right) \\
\hat{Y}_{0} \sim \mathcal{N}\left(0, \operatorname{Id}_{D}\right)
\end{array}\right.
$$

This can be proven by integrating the linear SDE (7). See (11) and then a discussion in Remark 17 for additional properties of this discretization scheme.

# 4 Main Results 

Before stating our main result let us introduce the discretization schedule, first introduced in Benton et al. (2024) which we use in what follows.

Definition 9. Fixing integers $L<K$, and choose $T:=\kappa L+1$ and $\delta:=(1+\kappa)^{L-K}$, one can take the uniform partition $t_{k}=\kappa k, k<L$ of $[0, T-1]$ and the exponential partition $t_{L+m}=T-(1+\kappa)^{-m}$ of $[T-1, T-\delta]$ for $0 \leq m \leq K-L$.

The main result of our paper is the following.
Theorem 10. Let $\mu$ be a measure satisfying assumptions 1-3 and let $\hat{s}_{t}$ be a score approximation satisfying Assumption 5 with $\left\{t_{k}\right\}_{k \leq K}$ satisfying definition 9. Then the process $\hat{Y}_{t}$ following (4) satisfies

$$
\mathrm{KL}\left(\hat{Y}_{T-\delta} \| X_{\delta}\right) \lesssim \varepsilon_{\text {score }}^{2}+D e^{-2 T}+\kappa+d \kappa^{2}(K-L))\left(\log \delta^{-1}+C\right)
$$

where we use $\mathrm{KL}(X \| Y)$ to denote the KL-divergence between the laws of $X$ and $Y$.
This bound consists of four terms: (i) $\varepsilon_{\text {score }}^{2}$ corresponding to the error in score approximation; (ii) $D e^{-2 T}$ corresponding to the initialization error; (iii) $\kappa$ corresponding to the discretization error for $t \in[0, T-1]$; (iv) $d \kappa^{2}(K-L)\left(\log \delta^{-1}+C\right)$ corresponding to the discretization error for $t \in[T-1, T-\delta]$. By choosing $K$ to be sufficiently large, we obtain a linear (up to logarithmic factors) in $d$ bound on the iteration complexity in the following.

Corollary 11. Under the same assumptions as in Theorem 10, for a given $\kappa<1 / 4$ and tolerance $\varepsilon>0$, choosing $L \simeq \kappa^{-1}\left(\log D+\log \varepsilon^{-1}\right)$ and $K-L \simeq \kappa^{-1} \log \delta^{-1}$, diffusion models with $K$ denoising steps achieve an error bounded as

$$
\mathrm{KL}\left(\hat{Y}_{T-\delta} \| X_{\delta}\right) \lesssim \varepsilon^{2}+\varepsilon_{\text {score }}^{2}+\frac{d\left(\log \delta^{-1}+\log \varepsilon^{-1}+\log D\right)\left(\log \delta^{-1}+C\right) \log \delta^{-1}}{K}
$$

Tightness of linear bound. In the best case, a diffusion model learns the score function exactly and is initialized at the true initial distribution. Let $\pi$ be a compactly supported distribution on $\mathbb{R}$ such that a diffusion model with a given discretization scheme and perfect score/initialization achieves an $\bar{\varepsilon}$ error in KL.

Consider the product measure $\pi^{\otimes d} \otimes\left(\delta_{0}\right)^{\otimes(D-d)}$ on $\mathbb{R}^{d} \times \mathbb{R}^{D-d}$. Note that its score function is $\left(s_{t}\left(x_{1}\right), \ldots, s_{t}\left(x_{d}\right),-\sigma_{t}^{-2} x_{d+1}, \ldots,-\sigma_{t}^{-2} x_{D}\right)$. So, by the tensorization of $\mathrm{KL}_{\mathrm{L}}$ assuming perfect score estimation and initialization for $\pi^{\otimes d} \otimes\left(\delta_{0}\right)^{\otimes(D-d)}$, the same discretization scheme as above will result in a $d \bar{\varepsilon}$ error. Therefore a linear dependence in $d$ is optimal.

# 5 Proof of Theorem 10 

We defer the proofs of lemmas to Appendix C. The main idea of the proof of Theorem 10 is to exploit the martingale structure of $\mathbb{E}\left[X_{0} \mid X_{t}\right]$, which we now formalize. We introduce the functions $m_{t}(x):=\mathbb{E}\left[X_{0} \mid X_{t}=x\right]$ and define a stochastic process $\left\{m_{t}\left(X_{t}\right)\right\}_{t \in[0, T]}$. Note that $m_{t}\left(X_{t}\right)=\mathbb{E}\left[X_{0} \mid X_{t}\right]$. The next result states that this process is a martingale.

Lemma 12. Define the filtration $\mathcal{F}_{t}:=\sigma\left(X_{s}: s \geq t\right)$. The process $\left\{m_{t}\left(X_{t}\right)\right\}_{t \in[0, T]}$ is a martingale w.r.t. $\left\{\mathcal{F}_{t}\right\}_{t \in[0, T]}$. In particular, for $t<t^{\prime}$

$$
\mathbb{E}\left[m_{t}\left(X_{t}\right) \mid X_{t^{\prime}}\right]=m_{t^{\prime}}\left(X_{t^{\prime}}\right)
$$

By Assumption 1, $X_{0}$ is a.s. bounded. Therefore the process $\left\{m_{t}\left(X_{t}\right)\right\}_{t \in[0, T]}$ is square integrable. So, the following lemma on the orthogonality of martingale increments can be applied.

Lemma 13. Let $\left\{M_{t}\right\}_{t \geq 0}$ be a square integrable martingale in $\mathbb{R}^{D}$ w.r.t. a filtration $\left\{\mathcal{F}_{t}\right\}_{t \geq 0}$. Then for any $t_{1}<t_{2}<t_{3}$ we have

$$
\mathbb{E}\left\|M_{t_{3}}-M_{t_{1}}\right\|^{2}=\mathbb{E}\left\|M_{t_{3}}-M_{t_{2}}\right\|^{2}+\mathbb{E}\left\|M_{t_{2}}-M_{t_{1}}\right\|^{2}
$$

We are now ready to present the proof of Theorem 10. Our first steps coincide with Chen et al. (2023a); Benton et al. (2024). We begin by decoupling the errors coming from score estimation, approximate initialization and SDE discretization. This is formalized by the following lemma.

Lemma 14. Under the same assumptions as in Theorem 10

$$
\mathrm{KL}\left(\hat{Y}_{T-\delta} \| X_{\delta}\right) \lesssim \varepsilon_{\text {score }}^{2}+D e^{-2 T}+\sum_{k=0}^{K-1} \int_{t_{k}}^{t_{k+1}} \mathbb{E}\left\|s_{T-t}\left(X_{T-t} \mid T-t_{k}, X_{T-t_{k}}\right)-s_{T-t}\left(X_{T-t}\right)\right\|^{2} d t
$$

Note that we get we get the first and second terms of the desired bound in (8) plus the discretization error of the ideal score approximation. So, it is sufficient to bound this latter sum by $\kappa+d \kappa^{2}(K-$ $L)\left(\log \delta^{-1}+C\right)$.

The next observation is that (5) combined with (6) gives

$$
s_{t}\left(x \mid t^{\prime}, x^{\prime}\right)-s(t, x)=\frac{c_{t}}{\sigma_{t}^{2}}\left(\mathbb{E}\left[X_{0} \mid X_{t}=x\right]-\mathbb{E}\left[X_{0} \mid X_{t^{\prime}}=x^{\prime}\right]\right)=\frac{c_{t}}{\sigma_{t}^{2}}\left(m_{t}(x)-m_{t^{\prime}}\left(x^{\prime}\right)\right)
$$

This implies that

$$
\mathbb{E}\left\|s_{t}\left(X_{t} \mid t^{\prime}, X_{t^{\prime}}\right)-s_{t}\left(X_{t}\right)\right\|^{2}=\frac{c_{t}^{2}}{\sigma_{t}^{2}} \mathbb{E}\left\|m_{t}\left(X_{t}\right)-m_{t^{\prime}}\left(X_{t^{\prime}}\right)\right\|^{2}
$$

Applying Lemma 13 with $t_{1}=0, t_{2}=t, t_{3}=t^{\prime}$ we get

$$
\mathbb{E}\left\|m_{0}\left(X_{0}\right)-m_{t^{\prime}}\left(X_{t^{\prime}}\right)\right\|^{2}=\mathbb{E}\left\|m_{0}\left(X_{0}\right)-m_{t}\left(X_{t}\right)\right\|^{2}+\mathbb{E}\left\|m_{t}\left(X_{t}\right)-m_{t^{\prime}}\left(X_{t^{\prime}}\right)\right\|^{2}
$$

Since $m_{0}\left(X_{0}\right)=\mathbb{E}\left[X_{0} \mid X_{0}\right]=X_{0}$, substituting (13) into (12) gives

$$
\mathbb{E}\left\|s_{t}\left(X_{t} \mid t^{\prime}, X_{t^{\prime}}\right)-s_{t}\left(X_{t}\right)\right\|^{2}=\frac{c_{t}^{2}}{\sigma_{t}^{4}}\left(\mathbb{E}\left\|X_{0}-m_{t^{\prime}}\left(X_{t^{\prime}}\right)\right\|^{2}-\mathbb{E}\left\|X_{0}-m_{t}\left(X_{t}\right)\right\|^{2}\right)
$$

We next formalize the intuitive statement that the discretization error increases with the time gap.
Lemma 15. For $t_{1}<t_{2}<t^{\prime}$

$$
\mathbb{E}\left\|s_{t_{1}}\left(X_{t_{1}} \mid t^{\prime}, X_{t^{\prime}}\right)-s_{t_{1}}\left(X_{t_{1}}\right)\right\|^{2} \geq \mathbb{E}\left\|s_{t_{2}}\left(X_{t_{2}} \mid t^{\prime}, X_{t^{\prime}}\right)-s_{t_{2}}\left(X_{t_{2}}\right)\right\|^{2}
$$

We can now use Lemma 15 and then (14) to bound the sum in (10) as

$$
\begin{aligned}
\sum_{k=0}^{K-1} & \int_{t_{k}}^{t_{k+1}} \mathbb{E}\left\|s_{T-t}\left(X_{T-t} \mid T-t_{k}, X_{T-t_{k}}\right)-s_{T-t}\left(X_{T-t}\right)\right\|^{2} d t \\
& \leq \sum_{k=0}^{K-1}\left(t_{k+1}-t_{k}\right) \mathbb{E}\left\|s_{T-t_{k+1}}\left(X_{T-t_{k+1}} \mid T-t_{k}, X_{T-t_{k}}\right)-s_{T-t_{k+1}}\left(X_{T-t_{k+1}}\right)\right\|^{2} \\
& =\sum_{k=0}^{K-1}\left(t_{k+1}-t_{k}\right) \frac{c_{T-t_{k+1}}^{2}}{\sigma_{T-t_{k+1}}^{4}}\left(\mathbb{E}\left\|X_{0}-m_{T-t_{k}}\left(X_{T-t_{k}}\right)\right\|^{2}-\mathbb{E}\left\|X_{0}-m_{T-t_{k+1}}\left(X_{T-t_{k+1}}\right)\right\|^{2}\right)
\end{aligned}
$$

Next, we will split the sum in (15) into two terms: (i) the sum for $t_{k} \in[0, T-1]$ and (ii) the sum for $t_{k} \in[T-1, T-\delta]$. In particular, the first term will sum over indices $k=0$ to $k=L-1$, and the second term will sum from $k=L$ to $k=K-1$. The first term (i) can be bounded by a telecoping argument as follows. We recall that $L$ was chosen in Definition 9 so that $t_{L}=T-1$ and $t_{k+1}-t_{k}=\kappa$ for $k<L$. Therefore for $k \leq L$, we have that $\left(c_{T-t_{k}}^{2} / \sigma_{T-t_{k}}^{4}\right) \leq 1 / \sigma_{1}^{4} \leq 4$. So, by telescoping we obtain

$$
\begin{aligned}
& \sum_{k=0}^{L-1}\left(t_{k+1}-t_{k}\right) \frac{c_{T-t_{k+1}}^{2}}{\sigma_{T-t_{k+1}}^{4}}\left(\mathbb{E}\left\|X_{0}-m_{T-t_{k}}\left(X_{T-t_{k}}\right)\right\|^{2}-\mathbb{E}\left\|X_{0}-m_{T-t_{k+1}}\left(X_{T-t_{k+1}}\right)\right\|^{2}\right) \\
& \quad \leq 4 \kappa \mathbb{E}\left\|X_{0}-m_{T}\left(X_{T}\right)\right\|^{2} \leq 4 \kappa
\end{aligned}
$$

The last inequality follows from Assumption 1 combined with

$$
\left\|X_{0}-m_{t}\left(X_{t}\right)\right\|=\|\int_{M}\left(X_{0}-y\right) \mu_{0 \mid t}\left(d y \mid X_{t}\right)\| \leq \sup _{y \in M}\left\|X_{0}-y\right\| \leq \operatorname{diam} M \leq 1
$$

where $\mu_{0 \mid t}(d y \mid x)$ is the law of $\left(X_{0} \mid X_{t}=x\right)$. Next, we deal with the the second term (ii) which corresponds to the terms $k=L$ to $k=K-1$. This term is bounded using the exponential partitioning of time gaps $\gamma_{k}$ in $[T-1, T-\delta]$. By the choices in Definition 9, we have $T-t_{k} \leq 1$, and so $\left(t_{k+1}-t_{k}\right) / \sigma_{T-t_{k+1}}^{4} \leq 4\left(t_{k+1}-t_{k}\right) /\left(T-t_{k+1}\right)^{2} \leq 8 \kappa /\left(T-t_{k+1}\right)$. Also recalling that $c_{t} \leq 1$ for all $t$, we obtain

$$
\begin{aligned}
& \sum_{k=L}^{K-1}\left(t_{k+1}-t_{k}\right) \frac{c_{T-t_{k+1}}^{2}}{\sigma_{T-t_{k+1}}^{4}}\left(\mathbb{E}\left\|X_{0}-m_{T-t_{k}}\left(X_{T-t_{k}}\right)\right\|^{2}-\mathbb{E}\left\|X_{0}-m_{T-t_{k+1}}\left(X_{T-t_{k+1}}\right)\right\|^{2}\right) \\
& \leq 8 \kappa \sum_{k=L}^{K-1} \frac{1}{T-t_{k+1}}\left(\mathbb{E}\left\|X_{0}-m_{T-t_{k}}\left(X_{T-t_{k}}\right)\right\|^{2}-\mathbb{E}\left\|X_{0}-m_{T-t_{k+1}}\left(X_{T-t_{k+1}}\right)\right\|^{2}\right) \\
& \leq 8 \kappa \mathbb{E}\left\|X_{0}-m_{1}\left(X_{1}\right)\right\|^{2}+8 \kappa \sum_{k=L+1}^{K-1} \frac{t_{k+1}-t_{k}}{\left(T-t_{k+1}\right)\left(T-t_{k}\right)} \mathbb{E}\left\|X_{0}-m_{T-t_{k}}\left(X_{T-t_{k}}\right)\right\|^{2} \\
& \leq 8 \kappa+16 \kappa^{2} \sum_{k=L+1}^{K-1} \frac{1}{\left(T-t_{k}\right)} \mathbb{E}\left\|X_{0}-m_{T-t_{k}}\left(X_{T-t_{k}}\right)\right\|^{2}
\end{aligned}
$$

Finally, we bound $\mathbb{E}\left\|X_{0}-m_{T-t_{k}}\left(X_{T-t_{k}}\right)\right\|^{2}$ via the following lemma.
Lemma 16. Let $\mu$ satisfy Assumptions 1-3. Fix positive $\delta<1 / 4$. Then for any $t>\delta$

$$
\mathbb{E}\left\|X_{0}-m_{t}\left(X_{t}\right)\right\|^{2} \lesssim \min \left[1, d t\left(\log \delta^{-1}+C\right)\right]
$$

Combining (16) and (17) with Lemma 16, we obtain the following desired inequality

$$
\sum_{k=0}^{K-1} \int_{t_{k}}^{t_{k+1}} \mathbb{E}\left\|s_{T-t}\left(X_{T-t} \mid T-t_{k}, X_{T-t_{k}}\right)-s_{T-t}\left(X_{T-t}\right)\right\|^{2} d t \lesssim \kappa+d \kappa^{2}(K-L)\left(\log \delta^{-1}+C\right)
$$

Remark 17. We return to explaining the nature of first-order correction in (6). In the proof, we control the discretization error of the backwards SDE by controlling the difference in drifts $s_{t}\left(x \mid t^{\prime}, x^{\prime}\right)-s_{t}(x)$, see (10). By construction, the differences are proportional to martingale increments $m_{t}(x)-m_{t^{\prime}}(x)$ as in (11). This allows us to use the orthogonality of martingale increments after that.

Benton et al. (2024) also leverage martingale properties of the score function. They note that $M_{t}:=$ $e^{-(T-t)} s_{T-t}\left(X_{T-t}\right)$ is a martingale. However, since they consider a standard exponential integrator scheme, the discretization error which is given by the difference in drifts $s_{T-t}\left(X_{T-t}\right)-s_{T-t_{k}}\left(X_{T-t_{k}}\right)$ is a linear combination of a martingale increment $\left(M_{t}-M_{t_{k}}\right)$ and the score term $s_{T-t}\left(X_{T-t}\right)$. The last term scales as the norm of a D-dimensional Gaussian noise vector. We avoid this problem by adjusting the discretization coefficients to kill the second term. So, the difference is only a scaled martingale increment. This enables bounds that are independent of $D$.

# 6 Conclusion \& Future Work 

In this work, we studied the iteration complexity of diffusion models under the manifold hypothesis. Assuming that the data is supported on a $d$-dimensional manifold, we proved the first linear in $d$ iteration complexity bound w.r.t. KL divergence. Furthermore, we showed that this dependence is optimal.

This result is equivalent to an $O(d / K)$ convergence rate in KL where $K$ is the number of discretization steps. A simple application of Pinkser's inequality gives an $O(\sqrt{d / K})$ bound for the total variation (TV) distance as well.

# A Elements of Manifold Learning 

We follow (Azangulov et al., 2024, Section 2.2) in defining the class of regular smooth manifolds of interest. We give only the bare minimum details required to describe it. For a more comprehensive discussion, see Divol (2022).

We recall that a $d$-dimensional manifold Lee (2013) is a topological space $M$ that is locally isomorphic to an open subset of $\mathbb{R}^{d}$. In other words, for each $y \in M$, there is an open set $y \in U_{y} \subseteq M$ and a continuous function $\Phi_{y}: U_{y} \rightarrow \mathbb{R}^{d}$ such that $\Phi_{y}$ is a homeomorphism onto its image. The smoothness of the manifold is defined as the smoothness of the functions $\Phi_{y}$.

When a manifold $M$ is embedded into $\mathbb{R}^{D}$, a key quantity Federer (1959) used to control the regularity of the embedding is called the reach $\tau=\tau(M)$ and is defined as

$$
\tau:=\sup \left\{\varepsilon: \forall x \in M^{\varepsilon}, \quad \exists!y \in M \text { s.t. } \operatorname{dist}(x, M)=\|x-y\|\right\}
$$

where $M^{\varepsilon}=\left\{x \in \mathbb{R}^{D}: \operatorname{dist}(x, M)<\varepsilon\right\}$ is the $\varepsilon$-neighborhood of $M$. Equivalently, $\tau$ is the supremum over the radii of neighborhoods of $M$ for which the projection is unique. The reach controls Divol (2022) both the global and local properties of the manifold.

In particular, the reach controls the scale at which $M$ admits a natural smooth parameterization $\Phi_{y}$ which will be used to control the smoothness of the manifold. More precisely, for a point $y \in M$, let $\pi_{y}:=\pi_{T_{y} M}$ be the orthogonal projection onto the tangent space $T_{y} M \simeq \mathbb{R}^{d}$ at $y$. Then Aamari and Levrard (2018) the restriction of $\pi_{y}$ to $M \cap B_{\mathbb{R}^{D}}(y, \tau / 4)$ is one-to-one and $B_{T_{y} M}(0, \tau / 8) \subseteq$ $\pi_{y}\left(M \cap B_{D}(y, \tau / 4)\right)$. Defining $\Phi_{y}$ as the inverse of $\left.\pi_{y}\right|_{M \cap B_{y D}(y, \tau / 4)}$, we have constructed a local parameterization $\Phi_{y}: B_{T_{y} M}(0, \tau / 8) \rightarrow M$ of the manifold $M$ at the point $y$.

We assume that the $\Phi_{y}$ are in $C^{2}\left(B_{T_{y} M}(0, \tau / 8)\right)$, and define $L:=L(M):=\sup _{y}\left\|\Phi_{y}\right\|_{C^{2}\left(B_{T_{y} M}(0, \tau / 8)\right)}$. From a geometric perspective, this allows us to compare tangent vectors at different points by applying parallel transport which is defined in terms of a second-order differential operator. Finally, we define $r$ in Assumption 3 as $r:=\min (\tau, L) / 8$.

## B Discretization Coefficients

In Appendix B. 1 show that KL error of exponential integrator (3) scales at least linearly with $D$ and identify the term responsible for this. In Appendix B. 2 we show that this term can be addressed by a simple linear correction and that the resulting scheme is equivalent to (4).

![img-2.jpeg](img-2.jpeg)

Figure 1: Illustration of a typical error of classic Discretization scheme. While point $c_{t}^{-1} X_{t}+c_{t}^{-1} \sigma_{t} s_{t}\left(X_{t}\right)$ is $O\left(\sqrt{d} \sigma_{t} / c_{t}\right)$ close to $X_{0}$, the difference $X_{t+\gamma}-c_{\gamma} X_{t} \sim \mathcal{N}\left(0, \sigma_{\gamma} \operatorname{Id}_{D}\right)$, which is of order $O\left(\sigma_{\gamma} \sqrt{D}\right)$. So, for $\gamma / t \lesssim d / D$ the error scales as at least $\sigma_{\gamma} \sqrt{D}$.

# B. 1 Failure of Exponential Integrator 

Assuming the best case scenario, i.e. access to the true score $\hat{s}=s$ and absence of initialization error $\hat{Y}_{0}=Y_{0}$ by Girsanov theorem Chen et al. (2023b) KL-divergence can be estimated

$$
\operatorname{KL}\left(\hat{Y}_{T-\delta}, X_{\delta}\right) \leq \sum_{k=0}^{K-1} \int_{t_{k}}^{t_{k+1}} \mathbb{E}\left\|s_{T-t}\left(X_{T-t} \mid T-t_{k}, X_{T-t_{k}}\right)-s_{T-t}\left(X_{T-t}\right)\right\|^{2} d t
$$

In the following, we present a simple, informal, argument showing the right-hand side scales with $D$. To achieve this it is enough to compare $s_{t+\gamma}\left(X_{t+\gamma}\right)$ with $s_{t}\left(X_{t}\right)$ and show that the difference between these vectors grows scales $\sqrt{D}$. The following proposition formalizes this claim.

Proposition 18. Assume that $\gamma<t<1 / 4$ and $\gamma \gtrsim d / D$ then

$$
\mathbb{E}\left\|s_{t+\gamma}\left(X_{t+\gamma}\right)-s_{t}\left(X_{t}\right)\right\|^{2} \gtrsim D \frac{\gamma}{t+\gamma}
$$

Substituting Proposition 18 into (18) we obtain either the number of steps or the error scale linearly in $D$. The rest of the section is devoted to the proof of Proposition 18.

Proof. On the one hand, by the properties of the Ornstein-Uhlenbeck process

$$
\begin{aligned}
& X(t)=c_{t} X_{0}+\sigma_{t} Z_{t} \\
& X_{t+\gamma}=c_{t+\gamma} X_{0}+\sigma_{t+\gamma} Z_{t+\gamma} \\
& X_{t+\gamma}=c_{\gamma} X_{t}+\sigma_{\gamma} Z_{\gamma}
\end{aligned}
$$

where $Z_{\gamma}, Z_{t}, Z_{t+\gamma} \sim \mathcal{N}\left(0, \operatorname{Id}_{D}\right)$ and $X_{0} \sim \mu$. Note, that $\sigma_{t+\gamma} Z_{t+\gamma}=c_{\gamma} \sigma_{t} Z_{t}+\sigma_{\gamma} Z_{\gamma}$.
On the one hand, by triangular inequality

$$
\left\|s_{t}\left(X_{t}\right)-s_{t+\gamma}\left(X_{t+\gamma}\right)\right\| \geq\left\|\sigma_{t}^{-1} Z_{t}-\sigma_{t+\gamma}^{-1} Z_{t+\gamma}\right\|-\left\|s_{t}\left(X_{t}\right)-\sigma_{t}^{-1} X_{t}\right\|-\left\|s_{t+\gamma}\left(X_{t+\gamma}\right)-\sigma_{t+\gamma}^{-1} Z_{t+\gamma}\right\|
$$

Finally, since $Z_{t}$ and $Z_{\gamma}$ are independent

$$
\sigma_{t}^{-1} Z_{t}-\sigma_{t+\gamma}^{-1} Z_{t+\gamma}=\sigma_{t}^{-1} Z_{t}-\sigma_{t+\gamma}^{-1}\left(c_{\gamma} \sigma_{t} Z_{t}+\sigma_{\gamma} Z_{\gamma}\right) \sim \mathcal{N}\left(0,\left(\left(\sigma_{t}^{-1}-\sigma_{t+\gamma}^{-1} c_{\gamma} \sigma_{t}\right)^{2}+\sigma_{\gamma}^{2} \sigma_{t+\gamma}^{-2}\right) \operatorname{Id}_{D}\right)
$$

On the other hand, by (Azangulov et al., 2024, Theorem 15), ignoring log-terms, with probability at least $7 / 8$

$$
\left\|s_{t}\left(X_{t}\right)-\sigma_{t}^{-1} Z_{t}\right\| \lesssim \sigma_{t}^{-1} \sqrt{d}
$$

Therefore applying standard bounds on Normal distribution with probability at least $3 / 4$ holds $\left\|\sigma_{t}^{-1} Z_{t}-\sigma_{t+\gamma}^{-1} Z_{t+\gamma}\right\| \gtrsim \sqrt{D}\left(\sigma_{\gamma} / \sigma_{t+\gamma}\right)$. So, with probability at least $1 / 2$

$$
\|s(t, X(t))-s(t+\gamma, X(t+\gamma))\| \gtrsim \sqrt{D} \frac{\sigma_{\gamma}}{\sigma_{t+\gamma}}-\sqrt{d} / \sigma_{t} \gtrsim \sqrt{D \frac{\gamma}{t+\gamma}}
$$

where the last holds by the choice of $t$ and $\gamma$ and since $t / 4<\sigma_{t}^{2}<4 t$. By taking the square and then expectation we finish the proof.

# B. 2 Modified Discretization Scheme 

As we saw in the previous section the source of the term $D$ in the difference $\left\|s_{t}\left(X_{t}\right)-s_{t+\gamma}\left(X_{t+\gamma}\right)\right\|$ is a $D$-dimensional normal vector $Z_{\gamma}$. However, it satisfies equation $X_{t+\gamma}=c_{\gamma} X_{\gamma}+\sigma_{\gamma} Z_{\gamma}$, so it can be expressed as a linear combination of $X_{t+\gamma}$ and $X_{\gamma}$ as

$$
Z_{\gamma}=\frac{X_{t+\gamma}-c_{\gamma} X_{\gamma}}{\sigma_{\gamma}}
$$

Subtracting it in the way that is demonstrated in Figure 1 we get the representation

$$
\left(\sigma_{t}^{2} / c_{t}\right) s_{t}\left(X_{t}\right)=c_{t+\gamma}^{-1} \sigma_{t+\gamma}^{2} s_{t+\gamma}\left(X_{t+\gamma}\right)-\left(c_{t}^{-1} X_{t}-c_{t+\gamma}^{-1} X_{t+\gamma}\right)+O\left(\sqrt{d} \sigma_{t} / c_{t}\right)
$$

Dividing by $\sigma_{t}^{2} / c_{t}$ we obtain $s_{t}\left(X_{t} \mid t+\gamma, X_{t+\gamma}\right)$ that we defined in (6) in the right-hand side of (19). Finally, substituting Tweedie's formula (5) we get

$$
\begin{aligned}
s_{t}\left(x_{t} \mid t^{\prime}, x_{t^{\prime}}\right) & =c_{t^{\prime}-t}^{-1} \frac{\sigma_{t^{\prime}}^{2}}{\sigma_{t}^{2}} s_{t^{\prime}}\left(x_{t^{\prime}}\right)-\frac{x_{t}-c_{t^{\prime}-t}^{-1} x_{t^{\prime}}}{\sigma_{t}^{2}} \\
& =c_{t^{\prime}-t}^{-1} \frac{\sigma_{t^{\prime}}^{2}}{\sigma_{t}^{2}} \frac{c_{t} \mathbb{E}\left[X_{0} \mid X_{t}=x\right]-x}{\sigma_{t}^{2}}-\frac{x_{t}-c_{t^{\prime}-t}^{-1} x_{t^{\prime}}}{\sigma_{t}^{2}} \\
& =\frac{c_{t} \mathbb{E}\left[X_{0} \mid X_{t^{\prime}}=x_{t^{\prime}}\right]-x_{t}}{\sigma_{t}^{2}}
\end{aligned}
$$

Finally, we prove Proposition 8
Proposition 8. The scheme (4) can be obtained by solving the following continuous-time dynamics

$$
\left\{\begin{array}{l}
d \dot{Y}_{t}=\left[\dot{Y}_{t}+2 \dot{s}_{T-t}\left(\dot{Y}_{t} \mid T-t_{k}, \dot{Y}_{t_{k}}\right)\right] d t+\sqrt{2} d B_{t}^{\prime}, \quad t \in\left[t_{k}, t_{k+1}\right) \\
\dot{Y}_{0} \sim \mathcal{N}\left(0, \operatorname{Id}_{D}\right)
\end{array}\right.
$$

We now show that the iteration in (4) is precisely the solution of the piecewise-linear SDE (7) integrated over each sub-interval. Fix $k$ and consider $t \in\left[t_{k}, t_{k+1}\right)$. On this interval, the SDE (7) is a linear SDE in $\dot{Y}_{t}$. In particular, one can rewrite it as

$$
d \dot{Y}_{t}=\left[A(t) \dot{Y}_{t}+\alpha(t)\right] d t+\sqrt{2} d B_{t}^{\prime}
$$

where

$$
A(t)=1-\frac{2}{\sigma_{T-t}^{2}}, \quad \alpha(t)=2 c_{t-t_{k}}^{-1} \frac{\sigma_{T-t_{k}}^{2}}{\sigma_{T-t}^{2}} \hat{s}_{T-t_{k}}\left(\hat{Y}_{t_{k}}\right)+2 c_{t-t_{k}}^{-1} \frac{\hat{Y}_{t_{k}}}{\sigma_{T-t}^{2}}
$$

This can be solved explicitly via the standard variation-of-constants formula which gives

$$
\hat{Y}_{t_{k+1}}=\Phi_{t_{k+1}}\left[\hat{Y}_{t_{k}}+\int_{t_{k}}^{t_{k+1}} \Phi_{s}^{-1} \alpha(s) d s+\sqrt{2} \int_{t_{k}}^{t_{k+1}} \Phi_{s}^{-1} d B_{s}^{\prime}\right]
$$

where

$$
\Phi_{s}=\exp \left(\int_{t_{k}}^{s} A(u) d u\right)
$$

Using $c_{t}=e^{-t}$ and $\sigma_{t}^{2}=1-e^{-2 t}$ we can evaluate the above integrals as follows

$$
\begin{aligned}
\Phi_{s} & =c_{s-t_{k}}^{-1} \\
\int_{t_{k}}^{t_{k+1}} \Phi_{s}^{-1} \alpha(s) d s & =\sigma_{\gamma_{k}}^{2} \hat{s}_{T-t_{k}}\left(\hat{Y}_{t_{k}}\right) \\
\sqrt{2} \int_{t_{k}}^{t_{k+1}} \Phi_{s}^{-1} d B_{s}^{\prime} & =c_{\gamma_{k}} \sigma_{\gamma_{k}} \frac{\sigma_{T-t_{k+1}}}{\sigma_{T-t_{k}}} Z_{k}, \quad Z_{k} \sim \mathcal{N}\left(0, I_{D}\right)
\end{aligned}
$$

Putting these together yields

$$
\hat{Y}_{t_{k+1}}=c_{\gamma_{k}}^{-1} \hat{Y}_{t_{k}}+\frac{\sigma_{\gamma_{k}}^{2}}{c_{\gamma_{k}}} \hat{s}_{T-t_{k}}\left(\hat{Y}_{t_{k}}\right)+\sigma_{\gamma_{k}} \frac{\sigma_{T-t_{k+1}}}{\sigma_{T-t_{k}}} Z_{k}
$$

which coincides with (4).

# C Proofs of Lemmas 

Lemma 12. Define the filtration $\mathcal{F}_{t}:=\sigma\left(X_{s}: s \geq t\right)$. The process $\left\{m_{t}\left(X_{t}\right)\right\}_{t \in[0, T]}$ is a martingale w.r.t. $\left\{\mathcal{F}_{t}\right\}_{t \in[0, T]}$. In particular, for $t<t^{\prime}$

$$
\mathbb{E}\left[m_{t}\left(X_{t}\right) \mid X_{t^{\prime}}\right]=m_{t^{\prime}}\left(X_{t^{\prime}}\right)
$$

Proof. Since $X_{0} \in L^{1},\left\{\mathbb{E}\left[X_{0} \mid \mathcal{F}_{t}\right]\right\}_{t \in[0, T]}$ is a Doob martingale. Since $\left\{X_{t}\right\}_{t \in[0, T]}$ is a Markov process, we have $\mathbb{E}\left[X_{0} \mid \mathcal{F}_{t}\right]=\mathbb{E}\left[X_{0} \mid X_{t}\right]=m_{t}\left(X_{t}\right)$. This completes the proof.

Lemma 13. Let $\left\{M_{t}\right\}_{t \geq 0}$ be a square integrable martingale in $\mathbb{R}^{D}$ w.r.t. a filtration $\left\{\mathcal{F}_{t}\right\}_{t \geq 0}$. Then for any $t_{1}<t_{2}<t_{3}$ we have

$$
\mathbb{E}\left\|M_{t_{3}}-M_{t_{1}}\right\|^{2}=\mathbb{E}\left\|M_{t_{3}}-M_{t_{2}}\right\|^{2}+\mathbb{E}\left\|M_{t_{2}}-M_{t_{1}}\right\|^{2}
$$

Proof. We follow the proof of (Le Gall, 2018, Proposition 3.14) with minimal modifications for the case when $M_{t}$ takes values in $\mathbb{R}^{D}$.

$$
\begin{aligned}
\mathbb{E}\left\|M_{t_{2}}-M_{t_{1}}\right\|^{2} & =\mathbb{E}\left[\mathbb{E}\left[\left\|M_{t_{2}}-M_{t_{1}}\right\|^{2} \mid \mathcal{F}_{t_{1}}\right]\right]=\mathbb{E}\left[\mathbb{E}\left[\left\|M_{t_{2}}\right\|^{2}-2\left\langle M_{t_{2}}, M_{t_{1}}\right\rangle+\left\|M_{t_{1}}\right\|^{2} \mid \mathcal{F}_{t_{1}}\right]\right] \\
& =\mathbb{E}\left\|M_{t_{2}}\right\|^{2}-\mathbb{E}\left\|M_{t_{1}}\right\|^{2}
\end{aligned}
$$

Applying the same calculation to $\mathbb{E}\left\|M_{t_{3}}-M_{t_{1}}\right\|^{2}$ and $\mathbb{E}\left\|M_{t_{3}}-M_{t_{2}}\right\|^{2}$, then summing up gives the desired result.

Lemma 14. Under the same assumptions as in Theorem 10

$$
\mathrm{KL}\left(\hat{Y}_{T-\delta} \mid X_{\delta}\right) \lesssim \varepsilon_{s c o r e}^{2}+D e^{-2 T}+\sum_{k=0}^{K-1} \int_{t_{k}}^{t_{k+1}} \mathbb{E}\left\|s_{T-t}\left(X_{T-t} \mid T-t_{k}, X_{T-t_{k}}\right)-s_{T-t}\left(X_{T-t}\right)\right\|^{2} d t
$$

Proof. We introduce the process $\left\{\hat{Y}_{t}^{\prime}\right\}_{t \in[0, T-\delta]}$ that approximates the true backwards process $\left\{Y_{t}\right\}_{t \in[0, T-\delta]}$ and is given by

$$
\left\{\begin{array}{l}
d \hat{Y}_{t}^{\prime}=\left[\hat{Y}_{t}^{\prime}+2 \hat{s}_{T-t}\left(\hat{Y}_{t} \mid T-t_{k}, \hat{Y}_{t_{k}}\right)\right] d t+\sqrt{2} d B_{t}, \quad t \in\left[t_{k}, t_{k+1}\right) \\
\hat{Y}_{0}^{\prime} \stackrel{d t \text { st }}{=} X_{T}
\end{array}\right.
$$

$\hat{Y}_{t}^{\prime}$ follows the same dynamics as the process $\hat{Y}_{t}$, but it is initialized with the true distribution $\hat{Y}_{0}^{\prime} \stackrel{d t \text { st }}{=} X_{T}$, not by Gaussian noise $\hat{Y}_{0} \sim \mathcal{N}\left(0, \operatorname{Id}_{D}\right)$. By (Benton et al., 2024, Section 3.3) and the data-processing inequality

$$
\mathrm{KL}\left(\hat{Y}_{T-\delta} \| X_{\delta}\right) \leq \mathrm{KL}\left(\hat{Y} \| Y\right)=\mathrm{KL}\left(\hat{Y}^{\prime} \| Y\right)+\mathrm{KL}\left(Y_{0} \| \mathcal{N}\left(0, \operatorname{Id}_{D}\right)\right)
$$

where $\mathrm{KL}(X \| Y)$ is the KL-divergence between the path measures of processes $X$ and $Y$. We bound the terms separately. Combining Assumption 2 with (Benton et al., 2024, Proposition 5) we have

$$
\mathrm{KL}\left(Y_{0} \| \mathcal{N}\left(0, \operatorname{Id}_{D}\right)\right) \lesssim\left(D+\mathbb{E}\left\|X_{0}\right\|^{2}\right) e^{-2 T} \leq(D+1) e^{-2 T} \lesssim D e^{-2 T}
$$

At the same time, by (Benton et al., 2024, Proposition 3), we have a Girsanov-like bound

$$
\mathrm{KL}\left(\hat{Y}^{\prime} \| Y\right) \leq \sum_{k=0}^{K-1} \int_{t_{k}}^{t_{k+1}} \mathbb{E}\left\|\hat{s}_{T-t}\left(X_{T-t} \mid T-t_{k}, X_{T-t_{k}}\right)-s_{T-t}\left(X_{T-t}\right)\right\|^{2} d t
$$

Applying triangular inequality we estimate from above

$$
\begin{aligned}
& \sum_{k=0}^{K-1} \int_{t_{k}}^{t_{k+1}} \mathbb{E}\left\|\hat{s}_{T-t}\left(X_{T-t} \mid T-t_{k}, X_{T-t_{k}}\right)-s_{T-t}\left(X_{T-t}\right)\right\|^{2} d t \\
& \leq 2 \sum_{k=0}^{K-1} \int_{t_{k}}^{t_{k+1}} \mathbb{E}\left\|\hat{s}_{T-t}\left(X_{T-t} \mid T-t_{k}, X_{T-t_{k}}\right)-s_{T-t}\left(X_{T-t} \mid T-t_{k}, X_{T-t_{k}}\right)\right\|^{2} d t \\
&+2 \sum_{k=0}^{K-1} \int_{t_{k}}^{t_{k+1}} \mathbb{E}\left\|s_{T-t}\left(X_{T-t} \mid T-t_{k}, X_{T-t_{k}}\right)-s_{T-t}\left(X_{T-t}\right)\right\|^{2} d t
\end{aligned}
$$

To bound the first sum we recall that by the design of discretization scheme $t_{k+1}-t_{k}=\kappa \min \left(1, T-t_{k}\right)$. Let $t \in\left[t_{k}, t_{k+1}\right]$. First, since $t_{k+1}-t_{k} \leq \kappa<1 / 4$ we have $c_{t-t_{k}}^{-1} \leq c_{\kappa}^{-1}=e^{\kappa} \leq 2$. Second, since $\left(T-t_{k}\right) /(T-t) \in[1,1+\kappa]$ we have $\sigma_{T-t_{k}}^{2} / \sigma_{T-t}^{2} \leq 2$. Multiplying, we get $\sup _{t \in\left[t_{k}, t_{k+1}\right]} c_{t-t_{k}}^{-1} \frac{\sigma_{T-t_{k}}^{2}}{\sigma_{T-t}^{2}} \leq 4$. Therefore, applying (6) we bound the first sum as

$$
\begin{aligned}
& \sum_{k=0}^{K-1} \int_{t_{k}}^{t_{k+1}} \mathbb{E}\left\|\hat{s}_{T-t}\left(X_{T-t} \mid T-t_{k}, X_{T-t_{k}}\right)-s_{T-t}\left(X_{T-t} \mid T-t_{k}, X_{T-t_{k}}\right)\right\|^{2} d t \\
&=\sum_{k=0}^{K-1} \int_{t_{k}}^{t_{k+1}} \mathbb{E} c_{t-t_{k}}^{-1} \frac{\sigma_{T-t_{k}}^{2}}{\sigma_{T-t}^{2}}\left\|\hat{s}_{T-t_{k}}\left(X_{T-t_{k}}\right)-s_{T-t_{k}}\left(X_{T-t_{k}}\right)\right\|^{2} d t \leq 4 \varepsilon_{\text {score }}^{2}
\end{aligned}
$$

So, substituting (22) into (21) we get

$$
\begin{aligned}
& \sum_{k=0}^{K-1} \int_{t_{k}}^{t_{k+1}} \mathbb{E}\left\|\hat{s}_{T-t}\left(X_{T-t} \mid T-t_{k}, X_{T-t_{k}}\right)-s_{T-t}\left(X_{T-t}\right)\right\|^{2} d t \\
& \leq 8 \varepsilon_{\text {score }}^{2}+2 \sum_{k=0}^{K-1} \int_{t_{k}}^{t_{k+1}} \mathbb{E}\left\|s_{T-t}\left(X_{T-t} \mid T-t_{k}, X_{T-t_{k}}\right)-s_{T-t}\left(X_{T-t}\right)\right\|^{2} d t
\end{aligned}
$$

Combining (20) and (23) completes the proof.

Lemma 15. For $t_{1}<t_{2}<t^{\prime}$

$$
\mathbb{E}\left\|s_{t_{1}}\left(X_{t_{1}}\right) t^{\prime}, X_{t^{\prime}}\right)-s_{t_{1}}\left(X_{t_{1}}\right)\right\|^{2} \geq \mathbb{E}\left\|s_{t_{2}}\left(X_{t_{2}}\right) t^{\prime}, X_{t^{\prime}}\right)-s_{t_{2}}\left(X_{t_{2}}\right)\right\|^{2}
$$

Proof. We recall (12) which represents the error as a product of two terms. Since both terms are positive, it is enough to prove that both terms are decreasing. First, a simple calculation shows that for $t \geq 0$

$$
\frac{d}{d t}\left(c_{t}^{2} / \sigma_{t}^{4}\right)=\frac{d}{d t} \frac{e^{-2 t}}{\left(1-e^{-2 t}\right)^{2}}=-\frac{2 e^{2 t}\left(e^{2 t}+1\right)}{\left(e^{2 t}-1\right)^{3}}<0
$$

So $c_{t}^{2} / \sigma_{t}^{4}$ is decreasing and $c_{t_{1}}^{2} / \sigma_{t_{1}}^{4} \geq c_{t_{2}}^{2} / \sigma_{t_{2}}^{4}$. Second, by Lemma 13, the second term is decreasing since

$$
\begin{aligned}
\mathbb{E}\left\|m_{t_{1}}\left(X_{t_{1}}\right)-m_{t^{\prime}}\left(X_{t^{\prime}}\right)\right\|^{2} & =\mathbb{E}\left\|m_{t_{1}}\left(X_{t_{1}}\right)-m_{t_{2}}\left(X_{t_{2}}\right)\right\|^{2}+\mathbb{E}\left\|m_{t_{2}}\left(X_{t_{2}}\right)-m_{t^{\prime}}\left(X_{t^{\prime}}\right)\right\|^{2} \\
& \geq \mathbb{E}\left\|m_{t_{2}}\left(X_{t_{2}}\right)-m_{t^{\prime}}\left(X_{t^{\prime}}\right)\right\|^{2}
\end{aligned}
$$

Combining these two statements, we get the lemma.
Lemma 16. Let $\mu$ satisfy Assumptions 1-3. Fix positive $\delta<1 / 4$. Then for any $t>\delta$

$$
\mathbb{E}\left\|X_{0}-m_{t}\left(X_{t}\right)\right\|^{2} \lesssim \min \left[1, d t\left(\log \delta^{-1}+C\right)\right]
$$

Proof. First, we note that $m_{t}(x)=\int_{M} y \mu_{0 \mid t}(d y \mid x)$ where we recall that $\mu_{0 \mid t}(d y \mid x)$ is the law of $\left(X_{0} \mid X_{t}=x\right)$ and so

$$
X_{0}-m_{t}\left(X_{t}\right)=\int_{M}\left(X_{0}-y\right) \mu_{0 \mid t}(d y \mid X_{t})
$$

Since diam $M \leq 1$ and $X_{0} \in M$, a.s. we have that $\left\|X_{0}-m_{t}\left(X_{t}\right)\right\| \leq 1$. Therefore, it is enough to consider the case $t \leq d^{-1} \leq 1$. In this case, $\left(\sigma_{t} / c_{t}\right)^{2} \simeq t$. We also note that

$$
\left\|X_{0}-m_{t}\left(X_{t}\right)\right\|^{2} \leq \int_{M}\left\|X_{0}-y\right\|^{2} \mu_{0 \mid t}(d y \mid X_{t})
$$

As shown in (Azangulov et al., 2024, Theorem 15), if

$$
r(t, \delta, \eta)=2\left(\sigma_{t} / c_{t}\right) \sqrt{20 d\left(\log _{+}\left(\sigma_{t} / c_{t}\right)^{-1}+4 C\right)+8 \log \delta^{-1}+\log \eta^{-1}}
$$

then with probability at least $1-\delta$

$$
\int_{y \in M:\|X_{0}-y\| \leq r(t, \delta, \eta)} \mu_{0 \mid t}(d y \mid X_{t}) \geq 1-\eta
$$

Integrating $\left\|X_{0}-y\right\|^{2}$ w.r.t. $\mu_{0 \mid t}(d y \mid X_{t})$ we get that with probability at least $1-\delta$

$$
\left\|X_{0}-m_{t}\left(X_{t}\right)\right\|^{2} \leq \int_{M}\left\|X_{0}-y\right\|^{2} \mu_{0 \mid t}(d y \mid X_{t}) \leq r^{2}(t, \delta, \eta)+\eta
$$

Taking an expectation w.r.t. both $X_{0}$ and $X_{t}$ we get

$$
\mathbb{E}\left\|X_{0}-m_{t}\left(X_{t}\right)\right\|^{2} \leq r^{2}(t, \delta, \eta)+\eta+\delta
$$

Choosing $\delta=\eta=\min \left(1,\left(\sigma_{t} / c_{t}\right)^{2}\right)$, we have

$$
\mathbb{E}\left\|X_{0}-m_{t}\left(X_{t}\right)\right\|^{2} \leq 4\left(\sigma_{t} / c_{t}\right)^{2}\left(20 d\left(\log _{+}\left(\sigma_{t} / c_{t}\right)^{-1}+4 C\right)+18 \log _{+}\left(\sigma_{t} / c_{t}\right)^{-1}\right)
$$

Therefore

$$
\mathbb{E}\left\|X_{0}-m_{t}\left(X_{t}\right)\right\|^{2} \lesssim\left(\sigma_{t} / c_{t}\right)^{2} d\left(\log _{+}\left(\sigma_{t} / c_{t}\right)^{-1}+C\right)
$$

As we mentioned, we can limit ourselves to the case $t \leq 1$. For $t \in[\delta, 1]$, we have $\left(\sigma_{t} / c_{t}\right)^{2} \simeq t$ and $\log _{+}\left(\sigma_{t} / c_{t}\right)^{-1} \lesssim \log \delta^{-1}$. This shows that

$$
\mathbb{E}\left\|X_{0}-m_{t}\left(X_{t}\right)\right\|^{2} \lesssim t d\left(\log \delta^{-1}+C\right)
$$

abstract:
Score-matching generative models have proven successful at sampling from
complex high-dimensional data distributions. In many applications, this
distribution is believed to concentrate on a much lower $d$-dimensional
manifold embedded into $D$-dimensional space; this is known as the manifold
hypothesis. The current best-known convergence guarantees are either linear in
$D$ or polynomial (superlinear) in $d$. The latter exploits a novel integration
scheme for the backward SDE. We take the best of both worlds and show that the
number of steps diffusion models require in order to converge in
Kullback-Leibler~(KL) divergence is linear (up to logarithmic terms) in the
intrinsic dimension $d$. Moreover, we show that this linear dependency is
sharp.
